caption.title: CONSORT diagram.
caption.p: Flow diagram illustrating the enrollment, allocation, follow-up, and analysis of participants.

caption.title: Percentage of the explained variation attributed to the diet intervention for multiplex / omics data layer.
caption.p: Histograms of the percentage of explained variance by dietary intervention in the switch from African heritage diet (AHD) to Western diet (Switch to WD), switch from Western to African heritage diet (Switch to AHD), consumption of the fermented beverage (top, middle and bottom, respectively). Variance partition analysis was performed considering the change in features in each omics layer between post-intervention (t1, orange) or follow-up (t2, purple) vs baseline (t0) measurements. Age, BMI and physical activity levels at baseline were included as additional fixed variables and individual ID as random effect. The percentage of features in each data layer that intervention contributed to more than 5% in its variance is marked in each plot.

caption.title: Principal component analysis (PCA) of plasma proteome and pathway annotation.
caption.p: Targeted plasma proteomics was conducted using the inflammatory and cardiometabolic Olink panel (Olink® Proteomics AB). Samples from N = 20, 22 and 22 individuals in the switch from African heritage to Western diet (Switch to WD), switch from Western to African heritage diet (Switch to AHD) and the fermented beverage intervention arms were obtained at baseline (t0), post-intervention (t1), and four weeks follow-up (t2). a- PCA was calculated on (i) scaled original NPX values, or (ii) scaled values corrected for participant ID. Dot plots depict the principal component 1 (PC1) and PC2, with color indicating the measurement time point (t0, t1 and t2 in green, orange and purple) and geometric ellipses drawn at 95% confidence for each time point. b- Dot plot showing the biological terms (derived from the Human Protein Atlas) for the differential abundant proteins in each intervention arm and time point comparison, with size indicating the number of proteins related to each term.

caption.title: Differentially abundant plasma metabolites in the intervention groups.
caption.p: Plasma metabolome was performed using untargeted metabolomics (General Metabolics, Cambridge, MA) to assess changes during the transition to a Western diet (WD), African heritage-style diet (AHD) and fermented beverage consumption. Samples were obtained at baseline (t0) post-intervention (t1, week 2 for the WD or AHD diet interventions and one week for the fermented beverage intervention, N = 22/group), and after four weeks follow-up (t2, N = 22/group). a- Dotplots showing principal component 1 (PC1) and PC2 from principal components analysis (PCA) of log2-scaled ion intensity scaled values using all metabolites as input. Color indicates the time points (green, orange, purple for t0, t1 and t2, respectively). A geometric ellipse is drawn at 95% confidence for each time point. b- Triangle plots present top differentially abundant metabolites (DAMs, adjusted P value < 0.05 and absolute paired fold-change > 1.2). Arrows’ direction (up or down) indicates the direction of change, comparing late vs. early time points in each comparison as listed at the bottom of the plot, with color fill depicting the log2 paired fold-change value for each comparison. Statistical analysis was carried out using a linear mixed model for each comparison, including time point, BMI, physical activity level and age as fixed variables, and participant ID as random effect. Asterisks indicate significance level based on BH-adjusted P value (*, **, ***, **** represents adj. P values < 0.05, 0.01, 0.001, 0.0001).

caption.title: Whole blood transcriptome PCA and enrichment analysis.
caption.p: Whole blood transcriptome data were analysed for participants in the heritage to Western diet switch group (Switch to WD, N = 22), the Western to heritage diet switch group (Switch to AHD, N = 22) and the fermented beverage group (N = 21). Blood samples were collected at 3 time points: baseline (t0), post-intervention (t1), and follow-up (t2), four weeks after the end of intervention. Five control individuals for each dietary arm were included in the DE analysis using DESeq2, with model design including the individual (ind.n), treatment (diet or control) and the time point (baseline, post-intervention or follow-up): ~ treatment + treatment:ind.n + treatment:time point. DE analysis was performed between each two time points using the Benjamini-Hochberg (BH) controlling method for P value adjustment and independent hypothesis weighting (IHW). The two-sided significance level was set to adjusted Padj ≤ 0.2, with no fold change threshold, a, PCA was calculated on scaled variance stabilized transformed (vst) count values. Dot plots depict the data on based on principal component (PC)1 and PC2 (x and y-axis respectively). Dot colors represent time points: t0 (green), t1 (orange), and t2 (purple). b, c - Tile plots display the log2 fold-change (log2FC) of genes related to selected GO terms enriched in the switch to the Western Diet (WD) group (indicated by color). d- Circular plot shows the predicted transcription factors (TF) and their targets among upregulated genes in the fermented beverage intervention group (t1 vs t0, based on ChEA3 analysis). Gene names are displayed around the circle’s perimeter, with turquoise marking the TF, and arrows indicating the predicted regulated genes.

caption.title: Plasma proteome differences in the cross-sectional 300 Tanzania Functional Genomics (300 TZFG) project align with changes observed in the heritage diet switch group.
caption.p: Results from the 300 TZFG cross-sectional cohort were used to validate the findings in the dietary intervention study. a- Participants in the 300 TZFG cohort (n = 295) were assigned, based on their food-derived metabolome profile, to a food cluster associated with a more African heritage-style diet (AHD food cluster; n = 138) or a more Western diet (WD food cluster; n = 157), as previously described9. b- Results of the Olink 92 inflammation panel were compared between the African heritage diet and Western diet food clusters using a linear model, correcting for age, sex and BMI. The dot plot shows differentially expressed proteins between the two clusters, with blue indicating proteins that also exhibited significant changes in the Western to heritage diet intervention arm of the current study. c- Combined violin-box-scatter plots present the levels of measured parameters across the two food clusters in the 300 TZFG cohort. Proteins levels are presented as NPX values.
Demographic characteristics of the study participants

table-wrap-foot.p: For continuous variables, data are presented as the median and interquartile range (IQR). For categorical variables, data are presented as counts with percentages in parentheses. A two-sided Kruskal–Wallis test was used to compare continuous variables, while a two-sided Fisher’s exact test was applied for categorical variables. One participant in the switch to WD group had incomplete metadata. Abbreviations: BMI, body mass index; BP, blood pressure.

sec.title: Peer review information
sec.p: Nature Medicine thanks Jiaqi Huang and the other, anonymous, reviewer(s) for their contribution to the peer review of this work. Primary Handling Editor: Ming Yang, in collaboration with the Nature Medicine team.

notes.title: Data availability
notes.p: All sequencing data have been deposited in the European Genome–phenome Archive under accession no. EGAS50000000317, hosted by the European Bioinformatics Institute and the Centre for Genomic Regulation. All additional datasets, including anonymized participant meta-data, nutritional information, circulating leukocyte data, whole-blood cytokine responses, and plasma proteome and metabolome data, are deposited in the Radboud Data Repository (https://data.ru.nl). Access to these datasets will be evaluated by a Data Access Committee to ensure compliance with the Tanzanian regulatory framework for data sharing (https://www.costech.or.tz/Files/Documents/1728287181.pdf). Researchers wishing to access the data should contact the corresponding authors Q.D.M. (quirijn.demast@radboudumc.nl) or G.T. (gtemba@kcmuco.ac.tz). Requests will be reviewed by the Data Access Committee and a decision will be provided within 4 weeks. Other databases used for the analysis include the dataset sourced from the Human Protein Atlas (https://www.proteinatlas.org/; https://www.proteinatlas.org/download/proteinatlas.tsv.zip) for the plasma proteome; the KEGG COMPOUND Database (https://www.genome.jp/kegg/compound/); the HMDB (https://www.hmdb.ca/); the ChEBI (https://www.ebi.ac.uk/chebi/); Metabolite ID Conversion (https://www.metaboanalyst.ca/MetaboAnalyst/upload/ConvertView.xhtml); the RaMP database (https://rampdb.nih.gov/) for the metabolome analysis; and GO (https://geneontology.org/) and ChEA3 (https://maayanlab.cloud/chea3/api/enrich/) for the transcriptome analysis.

notes.title: Code availability
notes.p: All code scripts used for the analysis of the data are available at https://github.com/TalPecht/dietstudy_Temba_Pecht_2024/.

notes.title: Competing interests
